_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.0 EXECUTIVE SUMMARY			
1.10 Accidental Release Prevention And Emergency Response Policies			
The Diamond Fruit refrigeration systems use anhydrous ammonia (a commonly used refrigerant for			
industrial systems) as the refrigerant. Given the quantity handled, anhydrous ammonia is			
considered a hazardous substance by the EPA.			
Many of the properties that make ammonia valuable as a refrigerant also require precautions			
and procedures be in place to protect employee and public health and safety during a chemical			
emergency. It is the policy of Diamond Fruit to be in compliance with all applicable federal and state			
rules and regulations.			
Safety at our facility is inherent on the manner in which anhydrous ammonia is handled. While the			
design of the facility incorporates many safety devices, and safe handling procedures combined with			
appropriate training of our personnel are key aspects to maintaining safety at our facility.			
We have a written Process Safety Management (PSM) plan that complies with the regulations			
stipulated by OAR 1910.119. A crucial component of this plan is the Emergency Response Plan,			
developed in compliance with the Emergency Response provisions of OAR 1910.120. The			
Emergency Response Plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordinating with outside parties.			
This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with			
unplanned events.			
1.20 Facility Description And Substances Handled			
-Diamond Fruit stores and packs fruit, such as pears, cherries, and apples. Production requires			
the use of a refrigeration system to preserve the integrity of our fruit. This refrigeration process uses			
ammonia as a refrigerant. Access to the facility is restricted to authorized employees, management			
personnel, and contractors.			
-The regulated substance handled at this facility is anhydrous ammonia.			
-The ammonia refrigeration system's maximum inventory is 25,500 pounds of anhydr

ous ammonia.			
There is no standby make-up inventory kept on-site.			
1.30 The worst-case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s), including			
administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the distances for each reported scenario			
Release scenarios were modeled using RMP*Comp, a software program developed			
by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) and EPA. Offsite receptors were			
defined using the Esri ArcGIS Pro 3.3  system. This system estimates the residential population			
within the circle defined by the endpoint of the worst-case and alternative release scenarios. In			
addition, it lists whether certain types of public receptors and environmental receptors are within the			
circles.			
1.40 General Accidental Release Prevention Program And Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps			
Diamond Fruit complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with applicable state			
codes and regulations. The design and construction of this facility was in accordance with published			
standards, tests, or recommended methods of trade, industry, or governmental organizations.			
Diamond FruitA¿s written PSM plan incorporates many policies and procedures to ensure safe			
operation and maintenance of this facility. Plan elements essential to the safe operation of the			
refrigeration system includes employee participation, process hazard information, process hazard			
analysis, operating procedures, training, contractor safety, pre-startup safety review, mechanical			
integrity, management of change, hot-work permits, incident investigation, emergency response and			
planning, and compliance audits.			
Training is provided to ensure that each employee involved in operating a process has been trained			
in an overview of the process, the operating procedures, and safety considerations. This training			
uses guidelines developed by the Refrigeration Engineers and Technicians Association (RETA).			
Only qualified ma

intenance personnel operate the refrigeration system. This minimizes the chances			
of inadvertent error in operation that could lead to a release of ammonia. Startup, shutdown, and			
any onstream adjustments are handled by these qualified persons.			
EPA FACILITY ID:			
100000158018 Diamond Central Resubmission 05/20/2024.			
		
1.50 Five-Year Accident History			
There have been no reportable accidents at Diamond Fruit in the past five years.			
1.60 Emergency Response Program			
Diamond Fruit has a written Emergency Response Plan to ensure that precautions and procedures			
are in place to protect employees and public health and safety during a chemical emergency. It			
complies with the provisions of OR-OSHA Emergency Response regulations, OAR 1910.120. The			
Emergency Response Plan includes pre-emergency planning and coordinating with outside parties.			
This enables those who deal with emergencies to have a course of action to effectively deal with unplanned events.			
The refrigeration process has backup prevention systems to keep processing malfunctions from			
becoming ammonia-release emergencies. If an emergency does occur, the following response			
personnel, facilities, and equipment are in place:			
-Emergency Alarm and Communication System			
-Evacuation Plans and Assembly Points			
-Personal Protective Equipment			
All Diamond Fruit personnel will be trained to fulfill their designated responsibilities in an emergency.			
1.70 Planned Changes To Improve Safety			
Any upgrades or extensive maintenance work performed in the future will comply with			
codes and standards applicable at that time.			
Mock emergency drills will be held periodically to maintain familiarity with response actions and			
identify elements requiring improvement.	
Diamond Fruit intends to address all compliance audit and PHA recommendations as soon as practical or at the every least, before the next audit and PHA due date.
